awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Alexander Shapiro is "Quantum Groups as Quantum Character Varieties and Their Representations." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Toronto, and the sponsoring scientist is Joel Kamnitzer.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of the project was to develop an entirely new approach to the theory of quantum groups. Over the past 35 years, quantum groups served simultaneously as one of the major tools in studying such areas of mathematical physics as quantum integrable systems, quantum field theory, statistical mechanics, etc, as well as one of the most active areas of mathematical research with connections to low-dimensional topology, representation theory, probability theory, and many others.

The guiding idea of the project was to find the "cluster structure" on quantum groups and apply it to a number of open problems. The cluster structure is a collection of coordinates, or generators, that allow to present an algebra, or a quantum group in our case, in an especially simple form. Moreover, there is a recent result to the effect that if an algebra admits a cluster structure, the cluster coordinates provide the simplest possible presentation of the algebra. Such coordinates were found on quantum groups of "type A" in our work and were later generalized to all other types in a work by Ivan Ip.

The main applications of the obtained cluster structure that we pursued in this project are as follows. First, we showed that certain representations of quantum groups are closed under tensor products. On an extremely speculative level, this result is analogous to showing that by colliding two elementary particles of a special kind one only obtains particles of the same type. Second, techniques used to prove the previous result, happened to be the main tool for proving the celebrated modular functor conjecture in higher Teichmuller theory (this is still a work in progress). The latter conjecture, roughly speaking, claims that one may assign certain algebraic data to 2-dimensional surfaces, and this assignment shall depend only on the topology of the surface and behave well under cutting and gluing of surfaces. Such a modular functor in turn has a potential for providing new topological invariants of knots and 3-dimensional manifolds. Finally, we used similar techniques to establish cluster structure on other algebras of interest in the field of geometric representation theory, which arise as the so-called "Coulomb branches" of certain supersymmetric gauge theories.

I am happy to report that most of the goals initially set up for this project have been accomplished, and that the obtained results have direct applications to various branches of mathematica and mathematical physics.
